title: Covid-19 but the staff keep going!
body: In the last two weeks I have had to speak to two of the GPs - 3 times - feeling that I was being bothersome with an infection I had. I was so anxious each time I spoke to the doctors as I knew the risks of the infection getting worse without the right treatment. The first doctor listened to me read my notes and took a pragmatic view of what should happen given the circumstances of only call appointments the second GP was equally pragmatic and thanks to their care  and attentiveness  I am hopefully on the right medication. The second GP spent took time to explain my results to me so I understood clearly what should happen, this at 5pm I am sure at the end of a very long day, I appreciated that extra care and reassurance. At a time when NHS staff are under so much strain I cannot begin to say how lovely the reception staff I spoke to were - kind and helpful.  Doctors have to work in these strange and frightening times and my experience of them was just amazing, they were understanding, Kind and supportive.  I really am lost for words - continuing to work and knowing the risks - but yet continuing to do their jobs. One of the reception ladies went above and beyond for me and I am so grateful she did because today I was able to receive some results which means I am now on a prescription that will help me recover and I know if it doesn’t I feel confident I can call the surgery if I need. In comparison to what other have had to go through I felt my illness was insignificant - but it wasn’t and being in lockdown and sick has been a really awful experience. I have to care for my mum who  needs shopping housework etc as she cannot go out and having to work full time has meant being ill wasn’t really an  option for me. My absolute heartfelt thanks and appreciation to you all at Croft !

title: Can’t fault the doctors but aftercare not great
body: I arrived today for my surgical abortion. Despite the fact I had to wait nearly 2 hours to be seen by the health advisor plus another hour on top of this for the actual procedure, I cannot fault the doctors and the anaesthetist who were amazing throughout and reassured me during the whole process before I was put to sleep. Whilst the care during my op was amazing, I felt that after the procedure I was rushed out of the recovery room despite being told I had to stay there for at least an hour to be monitored after having a general anaesthetic. I was also feeling pretty rough and in tears from painful stomach cramps. I hadn’t even finished the refreshments I was given to me 5 minutes previous before being told to go to the toilet get changed and leave. I was also given 2 boxes of antibiotics to take at home however, the nurse did not make it clear to me when I had to take them which resulted in me having to call the after care line when I got home. Overall not an unpleasant experience but I feel that the nurses could have been a bit more clearer with their instructions and allowed the correct recovery time before discharging instead of rushing people out the door which was a bit disappointing.

title: Great practice?
body:
They send letters littered with inaccuracies and irrelevant observations.
Their correspondence has contact numbers which are unrecognised numbers when  you try to call them. They  invite people to attend clinic  whilst in middle of a  virus pandemic ...unconscionable.
Their consultations are the usual spiel.

readBy.name: Essex Partnership University NHS Foundation Trust

title: Outstanding Doctors and great team ar reception
body: Just want  to take this opportunity  to thank the Doctors who helped me get to the right hospital and see  the right consultant who underwent a procedure to correct mistakes made during a major surgery in 2018. The trauma I went through with my family was just unbelievable. The outstanding work of the Doctors and the entire reception  team, very accommodating with my numerous calls for help leaves  me nothing but a heart of gratitude to you all. My family  and I have a very good surgery and The Lord bless you all.

title: Excellent service
body: I recently had a potential swollen thyroid and had a telephone consultation. I was fast tracked to the hospital. It was done very efficiently despite been in the middle of a pandemic. I was treat with kindness and compassion. I could not have asked for better care. We are so lucky to have the NHS A massive thank you Donna

title: Caring Professional Staff
body: I had to visit because I had been unable to get an appointment with my GP. The staff were friendly, professional and helpful and I am grateful to them for being able to see me

title: good
body: I had a telephone call relevant to my knee replacement it was dealt with efficiently pleasantly and I am always pleased with my contact with Dorking Hospital

title: Amazing care
body: The staff on ward 20 were brilliant. They genuinely cared about the patients they were looking after and it was so lovely to witness. Nothing was too much trouble for any of them, day or night and every single member of staff went that extra mile to ensure the patients were treated with respect and dignity while taking care of their needs.

title: Basics lacking training required
body:
Firstly when you call the gp you get a plain “hello” like a home number keep having to ask is that the medical centre. Some training required , also very dour and hard to hear them like they are bored. 

Services are clearly reduced since April , the mental health service just stopped.  Used to get weekly calls or visits for years.  

The manager I don’t think has been appointed as I asked but they seem not to know the name and even heard who is the manger being asked.  

Poor start but hopefully things will get better for this new team.  As a patient group member we are here to help but they seem very insular which for a new organisation is unusual would expect more excitement and communication with a bit of get up and go.

title: Great visit
body: Very helpful staff and got seen to as a walk-in within 2 hours. Might seem a long wait but with the COVID-19 pressures and everything I was pretty impressed with the way they're dealing with it. Promptly was seen and diagnosed, and fingers crossed on the road to recovery

readBy.name: Sandwell and West Birmingham Hospitals NHS Trust

author: K3lly82
title: Getting clean.
body:
In 2018 I almost lost my two girls and my unborn baby to social services. My drug use of heroin and crack was out of control. Social services said to me at the meeting we had in April 2018 if I didn’t start to buck up my ideas my children were going to be put in care. That night I went into labour and gave birth to a healthy happy little boy, from the day he was born I decided enough was enough and from that day I haven’t touched a single drug. I have been drug tested on a random basis every week.  
Throughout this whole experience my drug worker Cath has been absolutely amazing her continued support and effort has been fantastic. She has had my back through this whole thing and I will be eternally grateful to her and will always remember how supportive she has been on my road to recovery. Cath has been there for me in times of need when ive needed a chat and has attended meetings for me about my children.  
I am now over 2 years clean and I am doing a detox from my methadone out in the community. I have reduced from 90mls of methadone down to 25 mls. I am reducing 5 ml every two weeks. I have found the reduction a lot easier than I thought it would be and I can’t wait to be finally rid of methadone. I hadn't realised the name I called my little boy means “a gift”. And he has most definitely been just that. He was a gift from god a special special gift that saved me.

title: Disappointed and unprofessional
body: Unable to get through on the phones, when you do get through i was asked to call back repeatedly. Every request requires multiple calls and physical visits to the practice. The doctor was unsympathetic to my needs and comes across rude. The reception staff are poorly trained and often lacked knowledge of basic processes.

title: Horribly Rude
body: I struggle with my mental health and was seeing the home support team recently, after a crisis. I was discharged from home support and given appointments with a psychologist (despite having to wait a few months to begin these appointments I was very happy with the help they were giving me). However, when trying to obtain my repeat prescription a few months later, I found out that the support team had never sent a reference to my GP and therefore could not be given the medication I needed. I contacted the home support service to ask them to if they could e-mail over my reference so I could sort out my prescription, and was left in tears after talking to a certain individual from the home support team. They were extremely rude and unpleasant and they did in fact make me cry and leave me too anxious to call back, I had to get my mum to do so for me. In doing so she spoke to the same person, who continued to be rude, unhelpful and disrespectful to her. As as vulnerable young adult I do not expect this sort of unkindness from a person who's job it is to help - I was not rude or unpleasant to this person, I was just asking for some help, and to be treated this way in return is unnecessary. I had been really pleased with the help I had received from the home support team up until today, however, the treatment I received from this individual has meant my opinion has been swayed. Thankfully when I did finally have the courage to phone back the phone was answered by a gentleman who was extremely kind and helpful. It is a shame that not all of the staff are like this, especially when they work with people who are struggling.

readBy.name: DUDLEY INTEGRATED HEALTH AND CARE NHS TRUST

title: The staff act with care and professionalism
body:
As always, everyone at the surgery is showing interest in me zs a patient. I always leave feeling that I was in good hands, and I got all the answers I needed.
The staff went above and beyond my expectations once more.
Many thanks to each of them.

title: Superb Care
body: The Reception Team and Medical Team go above and beyond their duties of care and service. I see the Nurse Practitioner on a regular basis and she is very accommodating helpful and gives great medical advice. The Dictors are also very empathetic and have a great bedside manner. This is a great surgery.

title: Excellent care
body: I have been with Gas House Lane for many years, the doctors and nurses are brilliant. Their appointment system is great and you can get an appointment fairly quickly. Always a very caring and thorough service provided.

author: Loulou411
title: Prenatal depression, my pregnancy, delivery and stay.
body:
I had very poor mental health whilst I was pregnant, I had my baby in November 2019. This resulted in me worrying about my babies wellbeing and I did have several trips to maternity assessment, some were reassuring and others I was made to feel like a nuisance. I wrote a letter to the lead midwife and didn't receive any sort of response which I found extremely disappointing, I’m not going to go into detail about this as I went into fine details in that letter.  
I was having my appointments at the new victoria and a referral for the perinatal team was put in due to a preexisting anxiety disorder I have, I was told that I wouldn’t be getting treatment and support from them because of the anxiety disorder, I was sent to wellbeing glasgow and was eventually enrolled in a CBT class that was no use to me as it offered advise such as “try not to think about the things that make you feel anxious” when that was impossible because my main anxiety trigger was if my baby was ok, if he was moving - I certainly couldnt just switch those thoughts off. The fact that the perinatal team didn’t support me when they deal with the mental health of pregnant woman is extremely disappointing and I feel like things would be a bit easier and not as extreme if I did have their support.  
I was eventually referred to the day care unit by my consultant and went to see the midwives there, they were all fantastic especially Linda & Joan, They made me feel so at ease especially on my really bad days and made the end of my pregnancy so much better.  
In early November I went to maternity assessment concerned about my babies movements, Siobhan was the midwife looking after me and she and the doctor decided it was better for my baby and me to be induced and booked my induction for the next morning. (3 days before my due date) I went in for my induction at 10am and it was a fairly straightforward process, I went into labour at 3am successfully after 2 pessary’s and was taken to the labour suite not long after, everyone was great support knowing about how anxious I was feeling. Stacey delivered my baby boy and did everything she could to coach me, support me and make sure we were both well.  
I had a suspected infection and we were both given IV antibiotics. I was kept in a ward in the labour ward for the first night for this and was taken care by jill (sorry if this isnt the right name the days were a bit hazy) and she was great also. When I was taken up to ward 49/50 not sure which one it was, I was obviously more actively trying to breastfeed my baby and that in its self was stressful, there was a wonderful student nurse who helped me with breastfeeding positions, but I found that every worker had their own opinions on what was right and what was wrong when it came to the way I was feeding him, one thing was right to one and the next person said that was wrong, it was extremely stressful and I felt confused and deflated.  
My mental state got worse on the second evening & I was finding things very hard to cope with. I am sure all new mothers feel a bit like this but the head midwife put in a referral to perinatal mental health team again after that night as she could see I was struggling. (I was rejected from their care once again despite my diagnosis of postnatal depression)  
After the second nights stay with baby (3rd in total) I was ready to be discharged. I was sitting in my cubicle trying to feed my baby and was interrupted by a midwife who told me to take him with me to the day room for the discharge meeting. I unlatched him and carried him though, I was given into trouble for not having him in his cot (I was totally unaware and uninformed that it was the way I should be transporting him around the ward. ) once myself and another new mum sat down for the discharge meeting this midwife basically said “right I need you to ask all the questions you have about cot death” and then went on to tell me that I shouldn’t swaddle my baby, especially in more than one layer, which multiple medical staff had done to him in the hospital during our stay, and spoke at great length about cot death. I understand the importance of this but I feel like it should be covered during pregnancy not when you are holding your tiny newborn in your arms hours before you are due to go home, exhausted after the most trauma your body has ever gone through. By the end of the discharge meeting I was extremely frightened to take my baby home, this lead for an extremely traumatic first night at home where I didn’t want to be in the same room as him out of fear he would die.  
My partner and my mum were extremely worried about my wellbeing that night and when I had my first midwife visit at home she helped me arrange an appointment with a GP who prescribed me antidepressants. My baby turns 6 months soon and I am still suffering badly with postnatal depression. The midwives who visited me the first 2 weeks were amazing support, my health visitor (Maureen based in the govan health centre) has been my rock but I cannot help but feel there are some things that happened during my pregnancy that could have been done differently that would have reduced the severity of my postnatal depression.

readBy.name: Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

author: One In a 2 million
title: Breast Screening Service
body: I don't appreciate how I was treated by Inverness Breast Screening Clinic. My surgery was brutal to say the least. Unless you think its fine to be fully aware of a considerable hunk of flesh being hack off you with with basically nothing more than a tea towel over your eyes to stop you see the full horror being inflected upon. While my surgeon's secretary seemed to do every thing in their power to stop me getting treatment on time. I entered this clinic with non evarsive breast cancer and after fighting to get breast cancer in time. Left knowing that I was lucky to escape with my life

author: Tropical1979
title: End of life care at Priscilla Bacon Lodge during the COVID crisis
body:
I am disappointed with the visiting restrictions surrounding the COVID crisis. My father was transferred to PBL for end of life care post-COVID. The NNUH was much more relaxed in terms of visiting for end of life patients i.e. close family and no time restrictions. PBL is: the same person can only visit for the duration of stay and for a maximum of 1 hour per day. If the persons starts to shows signs of imminent death then you cant visit if you have had your quota for the day!  
I find this baffling for a facility dedicated to EOL care! I don't understand why the 1-hour rule is relevant for IPC issues? I'm visiting someone on a COVID bay so they already have COVID. I have also had COVID and therefore cannot see the risk? I thought the government stance was that you should relax these rules for someone in the last days of their life?  
I appreciate you are a different Trust to NNUH but you should all be broadly following the same rules surrounding visiting and be following the government.  
I've also got to say that the bay is not what I expected for EOL care, its very clinical. I am a health care professional myself but thought there may be some 'homely' touches to the bay to make it feel less 'clinical' for the patients and relatives. Whilst I highly appreciate the care and dedication from the staff I feel you could look at this as a Trust.  
Simple things such as take away the monotony of the 'white clinical' feel. Put some colourful pictures up at the very least? I was a bit surprised to see this after never hearing anything negative about PBL. As a hospice type facility, I would have thought these issues would not be apparent.  
Simple things like this can help the patients and relatives have a peaceful death and assist with any post-traumatic stress. I am more than happy to assist and give some ideas from an external perspective. The entrance to PBL is colourful but this stops as soon as you reach the bays. EOL facilities need to decorated differently to usual healthcare facilities. I appreciate IPC, but pictures do not interfere with IPC requirements at all.  
No issue with staff, they just weren't aware Dad had a CD player, didn't have his glasses on and TV not on. The glasses would help with one of his senses for his EOL care as we don't know if he can still see, but if he can, the glasses would help. All Dads belongings were still in bags, I thought all property was documented on arrival. I explained CD's would help Dad, again with his senses, but it appears they weren't aware he had this in his property.  
I am highly supportive of the staff, especially with the COVID crisis, so please don't take my comments critically. Hopefully, they can help you to see from an external perspective of someone who has never had to use PBL before. A doctor called me to explain Dad had arrived but I think a nursing call is required to go through Dads other needs other than his acute medical/nursing needs which was handed over.  
These things are important for EOL care and can really help a patient and family in their relatives last few days. This can assist with the patient's distress and the relative's grief process. By a nursing relative handover I mean what has happened twice at the NNUH when a dementia nurse has called and gone through his 'This is me Passport'. To give examples, things to talk about with the patient (in my fathers case his cat who he adores), favourite TV (you have loads of channels, and free not like the NNUH), favourite music, do they want headphones on, religious needs, personal care, bed positioning, what they were like before the palliative time etc.  
More of a social gathering of information but exactly similar to the passport I mentioned. To me, the more I write it seems like Dad has been dumped here and we are just waiting for him to die. It really isn't what I thought the EOL period would be like, make us feel like Dad is important to you, don't dump him in a bed with no glasses on, belongings still in bags, no stimulation from TV or music. I encouraged the NNUH to put Dad in a hospice and the care was great with calls from consultants etc. I really thought PBL was the place to be for someones last few days but at the moment I feel quite upset by the, what seems to be, lack of organisational care for my Father.  
It saddens me to say I wouldn't actually recommend PBL because of this. If I could, I would have Dad at his flat but this is impossible due to stairs and I would have nursed him myself. It just feels Dad is unimportant as you haven't found out anything 'personal and social' about him, just the nursing and medical handovers. These are important things as otherwise the dementia passport 'this is me' document wouldn't exist. I would have thought an EOL facility would have been different and much more switched on to these needs, so I am quite surprised.  
Mainly, I didn't want Dad to die alone in the NNUH in a side room, so I am glad of the care provided by PBL and the nurses being with Dad when he passes. Again, a lot of these issues are Trust-wide and out of the hands of the nurses. But a few points described may assist with the family and patient, the grief process and the final few days of life. Palliative care in my job is an interest of mine and I go the extra mile as I know what effect it can have on families and the patient. I have experienced the death of a young friend with family present and the experience was peaceful. I cannot think how this situation with my Father will be the same due to the issues I've raised and the overcompensating that the Trust is doing with IPC which is in contradiction to Government advice for visiting imminent EOL patients.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Norfolk Community Health and Care NHS Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)
Norfolk and Norwich University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

links.id: LACK OF CARE REGARDING PERSONAL BELONGINGS

title: Quick / convenient service at this horrible time
body:
I called up during the height of the coronavirus expecting there to be a long wait to receive service. However, after my initial hold time of 15 minutes I was hold by the receptionist I would receive a call from the doctor later that morning. who called me back within an hour and prescribed me with what I needed. She even sent the form to a Pharmacy closer to my new house.

Great Service

title: Rude and unhelpful receptionist
body: I have been to get the blood test done at the surgery for the last 2 years. when I phoned the surgery this time to book my next appointment as instructed by my GP today, the receptionist told me I couldn't because I was 'not a patient' there, refused to explain why I was able to before and not this time, refused to give her name and hung up while I was talking. Totally unaccesptable service from the rude, unprofessional staff.

title: Excellent GP Practice
body: Excellent GP Surgery.  The staff are very helpful and pleasant and always do their best to assist.  Despite the current Coronavirus pandemic putting enormous pressure on all NHS services, the surgery has maintained their excellent level of service that I have always received.  I wish to extend my thanks and appreciation to everyone concerned.

title: Feel valued here
body: Just moved nearby from London.So far, this practice has proved to be as a good as, and efficient as South West London. My needs so far have been minor but I'm impressed by the care and courtesy shown by the team at the desk and the doctor who saw me. Thank you!

title: Fantastic staff again!!!
body: Have had to attend a few blood tests recently and despite being under huge stress and pressure. Doctors, nurses and all staff have gone above and beyond! Had a dizzy spell after a blood test and the nurse ensured I was given biscuits and water to get me back on my feet! Little kindnesses make such a difference! Cannot recommend this practise enough! Feel very lucky to be able to register here.

title: Spa Medica Review
body:
I had cataract surgery in Jan and was one of the very few that had complications.
In dealing with these problems, i have been to 4 different surgeries ( because of the pandemic ).
I must say that having met numerous porters, drivers, nurses, technicians, opthalmologists and surgeons; they are without exception the most professional, kindest people you are ever going to meet.
With the complications, i always new that trusting in God ( and Spa Medica ) that i would regain my sight.
Thank you Spa Medica for your help in my journey, i have the deepest respect for ALL of you.
God Bless you all
Regards
Kaz

author: Laz
title: Great care at NHS Dumfries
body: Thanking all the wonderful staff at the Orthopaedics Department of Dumfries Hospital and in the Emergency and Radiology Departments of Galloway Hospital Stranraer for their dedicated and friendly care after my “DIY incident”. The level of service and professionalism was faultless. It brought me first hand experience of why UK people are so rightfully proud of their NHS free for all universal healthcare system. I am very fortunate I was back in the UK when this occurred. We have the world's best healthcare. Thank you NHS!

author: Old Turtle
title: Admission - short of breath
body:
Had two weeks of feeling dizzy, e.g. when I stood up / walked upstairs. Following a cycle felt very poorly, wife called the out of hours GP service who told me to attend ARI to have a cardiac enzyme test. I was admitted on Saturday morning 2nd May.  
From start to finish I could not fault the staff who looked after me, so professional, friendly, and uncomplaining about the additional duties, restrictions on working practices, and additional shifts and long hours. I was not surprised to hear this, my experience of NHS staff is that they are amazing ALL of the time and have easily risen to the COVID challenge!  
I was assessed for around five hours by the superb team of nurses, and cannot thank enough the young lady doctor from Northern Ireland who probably saved my life by spending the time to work out that I had probably had a pulmonary embolism.  
She sent me upstairs and later I had a scan that showed two blood clots in my right lung. I am very fit for my age, love cycling, and would have continued as a ‘west coast man’ until something gave out.  
Ladies, you are all amazing, thank you so much for the care you gave me!

author: Bromley
title: Stroke
body: My wife of 36 years had a stroke at home on Saturday at 7am. The paramedics came quickly and were marvellous. Ten days later and not a single phone call from the hospital to keep me informed or of progress. Have phoned the ward three times, the staff were lovely but all they could say was ‘stable, or ‘improving’. In light of the fact that visiting has been suspended because of Covid 19 I deserve more clarity and reassurance . Awaiting a call from the Consultant

author: yellowyn55
title: My care at Boston hospital.
body:
I arrived during the pandemic , when it was at its peak, everyone's lives still go on throughout this. The nurses were brilliant with me, I'd never been into a hospital on my own, and having 4 children I've been there alot! So it was a huge thing for me. Then I had to stay all day, I was made to feel very welcome, I was offered water. Cups of tea or coffee, and food, I can't thank the nurses of 1b for the care they provided me whilst being a day patient.  
So again to you all thank you so much  
X

author: Sarah A
title: Maternity care
body:
Whilst on holiday in July 2019, I was taken ill with stomach pains. I used the 111 service to access out of hours  
Care at Penzance Hospital where it was confirmed that I was pregnant. The doctor referred me to  
EPU clinic at Treliske, where a scan showed that I was 8 weeks pregnant.  
My darling son is now 10 weeks old and I would like to thank the staff for their support and  
care in the early stage of my pregnancy.

author: Docchan
title: Care
body: We can't thank ward 10 enough for the tremendous care and treatment my dad received they went above and beyond for him, my dad can't praise them enough. So thanks again.

title: saved my life
body: i was admitted to ward 25 the freeman hospital on the morning of friday 13th march 2020 after been assessed at the rvi after suffering with chest pains and breathing problems.After admission and several days of tests i had a machanical aortic valve fitted,which i did have problems with.I had an heart alblation which nearly solved the problem but eventually was fitted with a pacemaker which sorted out the problem.was treated very well by all staff during my stay which was in several wards over the period and eventually given my freedom on my birthday (28 march) of all days.Thanx to all  involved

readBy.name: The Newcastle upon Tyne Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent department
body:
I have ongoing treatment in the AMD clinic and require eye injections. I have always been treated by staff who are courteous and professional.
One suggestion, it would be wonderful if injections could be given on the same day as checkups to save a further visit, especially in the current climate. I know of a hospital that does this and it works well.

readBy.name: St Helens and Knowsley Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Very good practice
body: Prompt reply , got the specialist recommendation   I need it after sending a pic and explaining via text .

author: Bluebird17
title: My Dad’s care.
body:
My dad had been seen in out of hours at St Johns hospital this past Saturday due to abdominal pain and vomiting he had been having for about 9 hours. He was seen by a member of staff who asked questions and took observations, this member of staff then advised my dad that his stomach lining was inflamed and sent him home with omeprazole with no further follow up or investigations.  
This abdominal pain was quite severe and did not seem right, long story short my dad ended up in the RIE for emergency surgery to get his gallbladder removed. I understand how hard diagnosing can be and that people make mistakes and cannot be 100% right all the time as it’s just part of being human, however I’m quite surprised that no investigations were done such as something as simple as taking bloods which would have highlighted a problem.  
The reason I am posting this opinion is not to shame the staff involved but to just highlight that something important was missed and should be reflected upon.

author: A grateful ED patient
title: Fracture clinic
body: Had the need to use fracture clinic during the covid-19 crisis. Although some things have obviously had to change I. e. social distancing and ppe the whole process was effective, efficient and safe. The staff as always were helpful and friendly and a plan set in place for further treatment. So If you need to use the hospital for non covid reasons dont be put off. Thank you dri.

readBy.name: Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: Rice
title: Quality of care
body: I was recently admitted and discharged from ward 15. I wanted to express my thanks to the staff that looked after me. The care I received was outstanding. I was in a side room, but was never forgotten. My thanks go to Sr Griffiths for the care she provided, it’s a skill to make someone smile when you’re feeling unwell, she was always a pleasure to speak with and she spent time to listen. Again, my thanks also go to Carlos, again for the help and support he provided. However, one person the really made me smile was D. Her quick Witt, humour and general caring nature first things in the morning will never be forgotten, a true often forgotten star. My thanks go to all the nursing staff.

author: Loubs
title: Hospital Admission
body: I was in the hospital for a day surgery and I had to be kept overnight and was admitted to the orthopaedic trauma ward. I was very anxious as during this time I was alone and expected to go straight home. I was kept in Ward 33 overnight and all the staff were amazing. The nurses, health care assistants, student nurse and physio’s. I felt so much less anxious instantly and they looked after me so well. I know this is there job but they do it very well and I just want to leave feedback so they know how well they are appreciated. Thank you so much for your care & help!

author: LSNxx
title: Their care has not been compromised
body:
I've been registered at Holmside Medical Group in Newcastle for years now. I'm writing this in regards to their approach and care throughout the latest pandemic. It has been fantastic, their care has not been compromised. I've been regularly consulting with a clinician named Katie-Jo. She has been patient and caring in regards to my mental health and never makes me feel like a burden. I feel leaps and bounds better now compared to how I did when I first phoned.  
As a healthcare worker myself, I was anxious to seek help due to stigma but I am eternally grateful to the care that I have recieved.  
Thankyou so much.

readBy.name: Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

author: Jaz1974
title: Getting information
body: I know we are under lock down and that there are issues with appointments. I had an appointment at the oesphageal lab in rehabilitation at UHH before the lockdown that was cancelled due to covid-19 and I understand that lock down is still ongoing. However my symptoms are getting worse and I am now worrying about when I will be seen and I cant get anyone to get an answer. Can someone let me know when the department will re open so I can get the tests I need to help me?

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

title: Great service
body: Was hesitant to go and have my eyes checked for ?retina detachment in the midst of this COVID crisis. Just don't want to take the risk BUT the arrangement at the centre was good - guidance to keep 2 metres distance even in seating areas, sanitiser available, accompanied to the  etc consulting room. I had a professional check by a lovely young doctor and left re-assured. Thank you very much.

readBy.name: Sandwell and West Birmingham Hospitals NHS Trust

title: Very grateful for caring work especially now
body:
A patient for decades and impressed with the way staff cope, often under trying circumstances. 
But especially grateful and impressed now, during the pandemic. Could name individuals,  but that would perhaps be invidious, as everyone I have dealt with has always tried their best!

title: Really good doctors, sound advice and reassuring
body:
Although it is sometimes tricky to get an appointment at the surgery, any time I have been seen by a doctor they have been attentive, reassuring, offer informed and sound advice and make referrals where they deem necessary. I have received timely call backs from them in situations where they have had to seek advice from other professionals and they have made referrals to other services when they have said they would. 
Really recommend.

title: Life Saving Emergency Care
body: I was a very poorly lady when brought into Solihull Hospital AMU by ambulance in the early hours of April 3rd 2020, but due to the treatment and care I received in Solihull Hospital I recovered and was able to return home.Thank You to every member of the team for the wonderful holistic care you gave me and for the care you are giving to everyone in these unprecedented times.

readBy.name: University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust

title: Distressing scene at the practice
body:
I witnessed a distressing scene at the surgery today during the Coronavirus lockdown.  A very elderly lady - in her late eighties or nineties at a guess - queued up in front of me at the dispensary.  She appeared to have struggled to get to the surgery, being unaware that she would not be seen.  She had something wrong with her upper leg or thereabouts (I turned away so as not to intrude) and showed the dispensary assistant.  The assistant said she had to make an appointment and told her to ring the intercom bell by the surgery door.  She eventually did this but struggled with getting in the right place for the camera.  The surgery receptionist just kept telling her over the intercom that she had to go home and ring for an appointment, and never asked for her name.  I suspect she might have struggled with this or she would not have made the trip in the first place.  This was an instance crying out for some compassion and common sense, even if the receptionist had had to put on PPE to come out.  Or the dispensary assistant could have helped her.  Or the receptionist could have said someone would phone her.  Instead, the surgery had an unknown patient who went away confused and upset and may not have been able to do as she was instructed.

I emailed the practice manager rather than using this site, but received an automated reply saying that he was away from the practice with no access to email.  That is the only email address the practice gives, so there is no way to contact them other than telephoning.

title: Appalling service
body:
I was referred to this organisation by my GP in January 2020.  Health Harmonie could not give me an appointment for almost two months.  The person I spoke to did not know the area I live in and had no idea that the suggested places were a long way from me and difficult to get to.  
As I was in a lot of discomfort, I went privately, was seen within 3 days and the problem sorted and cured.
Over 4 months later, I am continually getting calls from Health Harmonie about my referral.
Not impressed and would not use them if this is the efficiency of the organisation.

title: Excellent service
body: I had a blood test today 5/5/20 please thank all your staff for brilliant service & help everything was organised & I felt really safe - thank you all regards Malcolm

title: Complete professional services
body: Very pleased with the excellent level of service from the point of booking same day appointment for a telephone consultation through thorough prompt diagnostic consultation with the GP to actual visit to the surgery, despite current Covid-19 crisis. Also very  pleased with the complete services of Health Care Assistant who went extra mile of reminding and carrying out the missed blood test in addition to an excellent in-house facility of conducting ECG test. Really appreciate the professionalism shown by all staff members. The sitting area was all well marked for social distancing, which gives added reassurance for patients who might still need to visit the practice for whatever urgent reasons. Well done Bath Road Surgery.

title: Great Practice
body:
I have always found the reception staff very responsive and helpful.When I have phoned for an appointment from 8am for a same day appointment, my call has been answered promptly and I have been given an appointment.
I have received excellent care from the doctors and practice nurse.
I could not be more satisfied with the care and service provided.

title: First class service
body: I have recently attended for 5 sessions of radio therapy, at the cancer centre on machines L3&L4. I would like to say what wonderful & caring people on these two machines are,they made me feel so much better by their attitudes, thank you all very much.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of North Midlands NHS Trust

title: Exceptionally Rude staff
body:
Me and my husband are diabetic and I called the GP for an appointment as my blood level is quite low and I was feeling unwell. The receptionists was by far the most rudest person I have ever spoken to. Refused to book an appointment and was would not helpful with getting a a prescription. I am still waiting for the Gp to give me a call back so I can some how manage to get my metformin. 

I will never recommend anyone this GP. 

Stay away from this GP, Protect the NHS, Save lives.

title: Excellent care received
body: Excellent care and swift service. I attended with chest pain. Despite the current pandemic I felt my health concerns were taken seriously and my health and treatment was their only priority at the time. Social distancing was maintained where allowable. I was very impressed with the care and service.

readBy.name: Wirral University Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Excellent Care
body: My mum was admitted into hospital beginning of April after contracting Covid 19 she was moved to the Oasis Ward end of life the staff were fantastic looking after mum in her final days we couldn't of asked for her to be in a better place or in better hands they did all they could for her and the knowing she was well cared for made it alot easier for us the family

title: worrying
body: A family member got taken to Russells hall 5 weeks ago. She contracted the virus whilst at the hospital but began to get better. In three weeks we were only able to talk on the phone twice to my family member, she suddenly started to deteriorate quickly and had caught the virus again whilst being in hospital. She was receiving end of life care for a week and when visiting we were only give a surgical mask, gloves and apron to wear we would have to ask for a visor. The one time we were told they don't wear visors but as we insisted they managed to find us one and after we wore them they were then clean and reused. Staff were very friendly and when we had some concerns they arranged a meeting for us to discuss some of our worries and concerns.

readBy.name: The Dudley Group NHS Foundation Trust

title: Very unhelpful
body: Surgery is generally very unhelpful. Four times I phoned to chase up a query and every time I had a different answer. It’s not very good when you have a serious medical condition.

title: Amazing staff member
body: My mum is on ward C30. I spoke with a female member of staff at 1752hrs 5th May 2020 and she was so welcoming on the call , listened to my concerns and went straight to my mum and comforted her as I was concerned about her frame of mind.  Thank you so so much.

readBy.name: South Tyneside and Sunderland NHS Foundation Trust

title: An Excellent Hospital
body: All the way from initial assessment, the actual operation and the post op follow up, the treatment and care that I received was first class.  This is an excellent hospital and the outcome for me was exactly as I had hoped for - a very succesful operation.

title: Excellent service from all at Trevelyan House…
body: Many thanks to all at Trevelyan House Surgery during this very difficult time.  I have received excellent virtual service via the mobile and video link from the receptionists and doctors on two different occasions.  All delivered very promptly and efficiently.  I am very grateful for their care and advice.  What a superb practice.   Thank you for everything.

title: Exemplary practice
body:
An exemplary surgery and 'beacon of light' in an NHS often struggling to deliver high quality services. In my experience, appointments are on the same day or within a day of calling , in a practice that offers a range of services including alternative therapies. 
This is a well managed, organised surgery in a pleasant environment- giving people who are unwell, the confidence they need to believe they'll  receive an effective, professional service.
In my view it really is a model for other surgeries and an example of  what can happen with effective leadership and a genuine commitment to public health. Highly recommend.

title: Fantastic Care
body:
I was recently admitted to the Urology ward (29/4/2020) with a very painful Perianal abcess. 
I was treated most proffessionaly with every bit of empathy and care any one could ask for. 
I would like to thank ALL the HCA's Nurses and Doctors for the awesome care that I was given, I can not thank you enough for this. During my stay I lost all my dignity but it never felt like I did, this was due to the awesome dedication of all those who were caring for me, again I thank you. You are all awesome people that are dedicated to the vocation you have undertaken.
Many many thanks 

Philip Carver

title: Fantastic practice
body: I had a telephone consultation with the doctor and was diagnosed quickly, reassured everything would be ok and my prescription was sent straight to the chemist at stonebroom for me to pick up. This was an urgent call and from me ringing the doctors to actually picking my prescription up was 30 minutes, it really doesn’t get better than that, especially when you need to start antibiotics ASAP.

title: The best hospital iv ever seen to and stayed in
body: Thanku Thoursic surgery team including the main man an still here not dead yet far from it all iv ever been though hospital s in out chest drain s all the Thorxs I kept having more than anyone for 2 years my lung kept going down every time only one brilliant highly trained nurse surgeon s could prevent this from happening again by doing Thoursic surgery lung part cut away yellow fluid removed from Lung bacterial infection 2 years I had this in my lungs stepping hill failed only the best at w shaw hospital no how to train team members staff properly as I write this am telling the whole truth this is the best hospital iv ever had proper professional care well looked after by all in w shaw my review for team members surgeon s means alot to me because if it was not for certain surgeons I would not be here today I'd be dead stepping hill are not highly qualified like the best at w shaw I rare w shaw the highest level 10/ 10 no other hospital is better or cleaner or better than all they s brilliant team members who work very hard I have one kidney part of my Lung recovered staple d scar s all over me am not bothered about scar s as long as am here today I keep myself to myself iv not got c 19 am OK fine  I bother with no one no one bother s with me strange world we live in today I'd like to thank all in you s at Thoursic surgery F1 ward as well as preop center special nurse who no s me she's they best brilliant highly qualified nurse I will never forget w shaw saved me from dieing way to soon thanku all w s 👍

title: Very impressed
body: Fantastic experience and service during my last few blood tests even during the pandemic. Easy to follow instructions, patient safety first and everyone welcoming and helpful when it's a stressful experience leaving home only for medical reasons in the current climate. Cannot thank everyone at Skipton General enough. Including the cleaning staff who moved their equipment so I could get through safely. It really helps when you are anxious about your health to feel this safe.

author: GGJ
title: Mixed messages regarding seeing dying relative
body:
Mixed messages regarding seeing dying relative receiving end of life care.  
My grandmother was admitted to hospital over a month ago as she fell and broke her leg. Since then she had a heart attack and developed peumonua. We have been told antibiotics are not working and she is recieving end of life care. She had a stroke in December and had not been home long, her carers had been pulled 2 weeks before she had her fall due to COVID-19.  
My mother has asked to see my grandmother one last time she was first told this would not be possible but then was told she would be allowed 1 hour at some point when they see fit.  
My mother was asked to pick up my dying grandmother's washing today and bring her fresh clothes. She went to A&E and asked to see my grandmother, the nurse said no. She went back upstairs and brought someone else down. Who said the nurse who said she would get to see her mum before she passes for it wrong. I have read on NHS Greater Glasgow that there are exception allowed for visiting: 1. End of life care. 2. Birthing partners. 3. Children in hospital. I understand Greater Glasgow is not NHS Tayside. However, this is basic human rights.  
I understand the need to keep staff safe and other patients but your staff came down stairs to collect clothes from my mum not wearing any masks and did not keep their distance, and bringing in clothes from outside a hospital, again this is contradictory. These nurses are going back to the ward where my grandmother is currently dying.  
All my mum would like is to say goodbye to my granny and be there in person one last time. That is not alot to ask.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

title: Covid assessment
body:
I am a 59 year old and have been in isolation in my home with my and daughter for 5 weeks. Because of my auto immune condition I have stay shielded for 12 weeks as advised. This last week I felt particularly ill with all the Covid symptoms etc. 
After numerous verbal assessments by clinicians I was referred to an out of hours practice in Dudley where I was lead to believe I would be physically assessed for Covid 19 as my condition got worse over the last few days. Wrong, he verbally assessed me again and suggest I go to any A&E as soon as possible. Why my GP didn’t suggest that I don’t know, anyway
I chose to go New Cross and when entering I half expected the waiting area to be overwhelmed with people reporting in sick with Covid. I gave my details to the receptionist standing back on a yellow line. I sat in a enclosed part of the waiting area.
I was surprised to get called by a nurse in a 10 minute despite how exhaustingly busy they are the background.
After being assessed the nurse brought in a doctor and confirmed after again explanations that I was coping well with my symptoms. given my readings he expected I would recover over the next 3 days given the length of time in isolation for past 5 weeks when I first contracted mild symptoms. I was told to stay off immune suppressants for week.
I wasn’t tested for Covid however the doctor managed to assure me not to worry as he could see I was anxious and shaking.
The doctor explained how bad patients are before they admitted.
Though I felt dreadfully unwell  I felt 60% of it was my in my head mentally putting me in panic mode. I went back home and slept better. I firmly believe the face to face meeting made all the difference to me by the professional team in the A&E department. Great and Friendly despite the incredibly busy tasks they are faced with everyday.

title: Brilliant service
body: I have used St Georges centre a few times for myself, my son and my husband. From a broken leg to glass embedded in a foot and small child cuts and bumps. These guys have always been fantastic. I genuinley cannot fault them or praise them highly enough. We have always been seen in good time and treated with respect and very professionally. Keep up the good work guys, you are doing a great job!

title: Great Comminication
body:
Very helpful to myself as I am a support worker for a client with complex needs 
The comminication from the surgery was spot on thank you

title: Video consultation.
body: Today I had a video consultation for my back pain. The doctor was brilliant and asked many questions as well as asking me to do certain movements eg touching my toes so he could see my back movements, he then proceeded to send back exercises for me to complete. I was very happy with what was done for me.

title: Waste of taxpayers money
body:
This is my second referral to healthshare,and its the second time I leave without problem solved,long waiting lists,  no hand on treatments,how are you different from me watching a YouTube video? I continue suffering from joint pain.
Unfortunately I cannot get rheumatology doctor referral unless healthshare says so. Thus means I will wait until my condition is severe and I will go to emergencies to bypass those horrible people.

title: Receptionist customer care
body: Absolutely outstanding patient care from the receptionist (J) when I really needed some kindness she went above and beyond to help me. Her telephone manner was kind and sympathetic towards me. Keep up the fabulous work especially when the world has gone crazy! Thankyou

title: Great communication and knowledge
body: He gave me great advice and was very knowledgeable in regards to my case and treatment options available. Addressed all concerns and was polite and friendly

author: Ajox984
title: Birth of my son
body: After losing my daughter in 2018, the midwives and all of the staff across the maternity unit/ Labour award could not of been more helpful and reassuring. They looked after me from the minute I went in to be induced to the minute I got in the car to come home after giving birth to him. The 2 midwives who looked after me whilst having him are seriously something special! I cannot thank them enough. Ever.

author: Plato1
title: Continuing care and support
body:
I started getting symptoms of Covid in early April and two days later my Mum had the same symptoms. Though I struggled with the symptoms Mums situation was getting worse.  
Dr Suen and Dr Liu kept in regular contact with us and tried very hard to persuade mum to go to the hospital as mum situation was getting worse but mum kept on refusing to go to hospital because she was afraid of the worse. Though mum kept on refusing to go to hospital Dr Suen and Dr Liu kept on calling trying to persuade mum that she must go to hospital and as her situation was getting more serious she finally agreed to go to hospital.  
When mum got to the hospital she went to A&E majors and after was admitted to the ward. Mum had an x ray done and a CT done and they found that mum had a blood clot on one of her lungs. They started antibiotics and a blood thinning medication to get rid of the blood clot in the lung. When the consultant saw mum the day after she was admitted he told her that she was very lucky to have survived because people with underlying health issues as mum has don’t usually pull through in these types of circumstances.  
That my Mum is still alive today is because of the perseverance of Dr Suen and Dr Liu in persuading mum that she must not be afraid to go to hospital and when she finally agreed to go to the hospital they gave her the medication she needed to stay alive.  
Dr Suen and Dr Liu are both great assets of the Lawson Practice.  
Dear Dr Suen and Dr Liu I am indebted to you both and I want to say a very big thank you from the bottom of my heart. Thank you so very much you are both an honour to your profession.

author: 51johnboy
title: First disappointment in 2 years
body:
I attended WGH OPD today for a CT Scan, one of many I’ve had in the past 2 years. Until now I’ve had nothing but praise but I’m afraid I have no cause for further praise.  
Whilst I totally appreciate the pressures that staff are under today I encountered the following:- having sat in the waiting room for 90 minutes I decided to check that my appointment hadn’t been overlooked. What prompted that? It wasn’t the length of time but the fact that two people who’d arrived some time after me were called before me.  
Whilst a nurse went to check, as I was waiting another patient approached the reception desk to check in. I overheard the reception ask if she was a “shielding” patient - she was (as am I but I hadn’t been asked!) and she was told to wait a moment as they needed to provide a mask and gloves. When I questioned this I was told, despite having had my shielding letter some 5 weeks earlier, their records didn’t reflect my status.  
Then the nurse returned to inform me that an emergency patient had arrived which had put me back. She also admitted that I should have been advised that this was the case. At this point I was quickly processed, canula then scan, restoring my long held faith.  
However the conclusion to my visit was a sorry one. Walking down the corridor on my way out passing another reception area four porters, three of whom wore face masks, the fourth not and a nurse were in conversation across the width of the corridor. I stopped and looked at the porter without the mask and asked if I could pass as there was NOT enough space to permit social distancing. At this they stepped aside clearly unhappy at my comment. I did hear the comment from the group to the tune of “it takes all kinds eh?” This didn’t impress me.  
I’m sorry I’ve felt inclined to tell this story but I feel there are few lessons to be learned in the hope that others don’t encounter similar issues.

title: Excellent service
body: During the covid-19 pandemic, I needed to visit my GP. I arranged for a GP to contact me via a video call. I received a text message with a link to the video call, which was very easy to use. The video call allowed me to discuss my problem and show the GP physical evidence. Overall I think this was a brilliant use of technology under the circumstances and I hope this is utilised going forward, as it will save a lot of time and allow more patients to be looked at.

title: Very good experience
body: The doctor i saw was very lovely and gentle. Didnt wait long either. Overall very good :) keep up the hard work! Stay safe!

title: First class service
body: I came into Scot dental on 5th May to be met at the door by a friendly lady who took me into the surgery where i was met by two lovely girls who helped me to relax and make me feel comfortable as they took my tooth out which had an abyss and was very painful. I am full of praise for how they went about there work in what must have been a tricky operation for them. MANY THANKS.

author: branpt84
title: The birth of my son, April 2020
body:
I was recently due in for an elective caesarean. I woke up that morning with complete anxiety that it was all going to go wrong and that there would complications during it. I was met by a midwife called Gillian who was so kind and reassuring and gave me rough time frames of when each thing would happen.  
Following that, I met with the two most amazing midwifes and anaesthetist who would be with me & my partner during my birth called Marj and Maryann, and the anaesthetist Sarah. These 3 amazing woman kept me extremely calm and relaxed as well as my partner throughout the whole process to the point I actually never knew they had started the procedure until minutes before our baby boy was born! There was just constant positivity in the room and they all made the experience the complete opposite from what my brain had mapped it out to be. They took amazing care of me as well as my partner during the procedure and we can’t thank them enough for the extreme amount of care taken on such a special day. I really hope they know how much of a great job they are doing.  
I would like to thank the amazing surgeons as well who I never caught the names of, but a massive massive thank you for taking amazing care of me during my operation and delivering our precious baby safely! Again I hope they know how amazing they are doing.  
Then onto the ward - I was transferred to ward 47 where, again I was taken care of tremendously. All of the midwifes/doctors on ward 47 are amazing! And we’re there in a flash the minute I needed them with again constant reassurance and kindness. There is one midwife who dealt with me most during that night and the next day her name was Rebecca. She was so patient & kind to me and made me feel so safe again I hope she knows how much of an amazing job she is doing and what a great person she is. I’d like to point out that I actually was made to feel safer in hospital than out with covid 19 going on! Other than the PPE, I completely forgot all about it whilst in hospital. I was just so focused on my perfect baby boy. I really hope others who are due to give birth can see this and see how cared for you are and feel reassured.  
Thank you so much from the bottom of my heart to all of the staff who dealt with me. I will be forever grateful. Stay safe ❤️ xxx

author: Bluebird17
title: My dads care.
body:
My dad was admitted from the surgical assessment unit into day surgery with Cholecystitis, he then had emergency surgery to get his gallbladder removed.  
I just want to say a massive thank you to all staff involved in his care, he has spoken so highly of domestic staff, porters, doctors, nurses, the anaesthetic team, the theatre team, staff in the day surgery unit and staff in the surgical assessment unit. Thank you all for your professional, compassionate and brilliant care it really means a lot!

author: KelB
title: Fed up with service
body:
I have been a patient at Recovery Team West Cardinal Road for about 5 years now. I have complained before about the service through the Patient Advice Liaison Service.  
I was due to have a telephone appointment with my doctor (unsure of the name, as the doctor keeps changing) in late April. I had called on three different occasions before that date to confirm that the appointment was still going ahead due to coronavirus. I was reassured on all three occasions that the doctor will call me as arranged.  
On the day of the appointment, I did not receive any phone call. So I called the Recovery Team West on numerous occasions which all went unanswered. I then gave up and called the single point of access and they could not get through to them either. I then kept calling the team and finally someone answered the phone, I was told all the appointments were cancelled many weeks ago and that another appointment could not be booked as they are changing the appointment system. Once that's complete, a doctor will risk assess patients and book appointments accordingly.  
This was a terrible response. I had waited for this appointment for many months and have not been seen since last year. I then called to speak to a manager, I was told they were unavailable and they would pass a message on. To this day nobody has called me. I have had enough of the terrible service from this team, to not answering the phone, rude staff, promises that are never carried out and just the overall lack of care for the patients.  
In my experience, none of the doctors seem to stay at this team for long which is more concerning.

author: HelM
title: They have been utterly outstanding
body:
We have used Stonehaven Medical Centre since moving to the town 20 years ago and their service has always been excellent. However, in the last three weeks they have been utterly outstanding - let alone in the face of the biggest medical challenge in living memory.  
My husband and I have both had to contact the surgery on more than one occasion since the Covid lockdown using the e-consult system, and without exception received an appropriate reply within 45 minutes of doing so. At the surgery the Covid precautions were extremely thoroughly handled in a calm, friendly and professional way.  
Unfortunately, my husband had to have a short spell in hospital. After getting home one of the GPs took the time call and check on his progress, chatting through events at length.  
Sincere thanks to Doctors Howard & Dossett and all the staff at Stonehaven Medical Centre. Thanks too to the on call GP at Kincardine Hospital and the staff of Aberdeen Royal Indirmary’s A & E Dept and Ward 103. Our NHS is truly precious.

author: crocodilezc97
title: I was so thankful.
body:
I was working a busy 12 hour shift and suffering from a UTI. Unfortunately my work was far too busy/ short staffed to let me leave/take sick time.  
I tried to call my local doctors to see if they could leave me a prescription however I missed their call back.  
I called NHS 24 at 6pm and by 6.40 after speaking to a lovely ANNP Kay from GMeds hub in Aberdeen (I presume) I had a prescription which I could go and pick up after my work.  
I initially missed Kay's 1st call back, she left me a voicemail reassuring me that she would keep trying which she did until she got me.  
We had just gone into lockdown and i knew I wouldn't make the pharmacy before it closed. I was so thankful for Kay, who understood the situation I was in and helped me receive my antibiotics super quick.  
Thank you again Kay and NHS!

author: SHAZ S
title: Having my baby
body:
Hello guys I had my baby recently in the Princess Royal Maternity Hospital in Glasgow and the girls were fab with me. From being on the induced ward to the labour suite, to being in ward 73 after baby had arrived, to then go to the room in the ward with my girl I couldn't have done it without all the help all the staff gave me.  
At the time as I had preeclampsia, strep b and high blood pressure so to say the least it was a hard pregnancy. I am so thankful and glad my wee tiny baby arrived safe and well so I would like to say a big huge thank you to all the staff at the Princess Royal for everything they do for me and my girl 😘💜  
I hope you are all keeping safe and we both send our love xXx

author: Star82
title: Thank you for midwives
body:
It has taken me 6months to get time to write this but I felt today was apt with it being midwifery day & it is 6months exactly since these wonderful midwives supported me.  
Back in November I presented at AMU outpatients for assessment in the early morning after my waters broke the night before. I met a lovely friendly midwife Rhiannon, she was newly qualified & I would never have known unless it came up in conversation. She told me the doctor wanted me induced, this I may say was without seeing this doctor or any signs baby was is distress. Reluctantly we headed off to the inpatient ward for the process to start. Here we met yet another great midwife Hazel, she sensed my apprehension about induction without me saying a word and decided to put me on a CTG to check on baby, look again at my contractions & then chat about induction.  
From these results she felt induction wouldn’t be needed & informed the doctor of this (who again I had yet to meet, it is now 12:30ish) and they were happy to hold off and watch & see. Hazel checked on us throughout the afternoon, her care for the women also in my room was clear. Come early evening things were much the same & no signs of baby was in a rush to come see us. Hazel informed me the doctor was in touch for an update & wanted to come chat to me about induction. Hazel was due to go off shift but chatted to me about this & reassured me that I had choices & it would soon prove this chat was so valuable to me to give me confidence at this vulnerable time to not be forced into something. I cannot thank Hazel enough for being my advocate & reassure me I had a voice, it was lovely to see her the next day in the midwifery suite. She popped in to see how we had got on when down in the suite, truly showing her genuine interest in the women she cares for.  
Anyway the doctor I finally got to meet at after 8pm, who gave me two choices,  
1. They told me the labour ward was currently quiet so I could be induced now or,  
2. I could wait until morning for induction but they wouldn’t be able to guarantee when the labour ward would be able to take me as it maybe busier by then!!  
I kid you not that was the options they gave me, my husband was there & heard it all too. Now by this point it had been hours since I had been on a CTG & they gave me no clinical reason to move to induction. I in fact asked them if there was any risk to my baby at this point as they hadn’t mentioned any reason why we needed induced. At this point they said they did ask for another CTG & checked how dilated I was. I opted for an induction in the morning, it was clear they weren't happy about it by their tone & manner. Again thank goodness for Hazel my midwife talking to me beforehand as I feel otherwise I may have felt coerced into this induction by the doctor.  
My care was now under yet another wonderful midwife call Danika, my labour started to progress quickly and I was soon moved to the midwifery suite by her, though she cared for me briefly, her words of comfort & making attempts to get me moved ASAP will be always remembered.  
We then met Deborah, who was on shift alone in the midwifery suite with a bank nurse to assist her. She helped guide us through options, such as pain relief, birth pool, aromatherapy scents etc. I was left in the care of a midwife called Dawn when Deborah needed breaks & again though we met Dawn briefly, she took left a lasting positive impression on us.  
So after my waters finally break (turns out not all of them had gone) my little girl arrived very swiftly after this.  
Though a long story I wanted to convey that each midwife I met that day & my final midwife Kirsten who discharged us all left a lasting impression for myself & my husband. They listened to us, got to know us & our baby was at the forefront of their care even in the short time we met some of them. I am thankful for all of them & that because of them I didn’t feel bullied into an induction when clearly this was not required.  
Thank you and your management team should be proud of you.

title: Excellent Service
body:
I was referred to the practice by my GP for what was potential skin cancer. Both the GP that I saw and the reception staff were excellent and efficient. 
I must say that it was a pleasure to encounter such high levels of customer care - so rare these days. 
This practice does deserve the highest praise.

title: Difficult times being over come
body: Consultation only by phone but quick tests for blood and quick response. Good and fast connection with the hospital with quick turn around on results

title: Excellent practice
body: Very impressed by all staff. Receptionist very helpful and professional. Consultation very thorough and well explained. I really recommend this practice, it’s the most welcoming consultation I have had for a long time. Thank you.

title: Fantastic care
body: I had to visit A&E with a suspected minor stroke. The nurse's  and doctor's were fantastic in such a difficult time we are in. Had to go back for a scan the day after and the service and staff were just as brilliant. Thank you all at airedale

title: Wonderful despite the circumstances
body: From the antenatal day service, triage to delivery the service I was provided was tailored, considerate and thorough. I was never made to feel silly for coming in, even for something small. The women who delivered my baby were incredible despite the current circumstances. Staff were very very busy but you could tell they were all trying their hardest to do their best job. Thank you so much - to everyone from maternity assistants, anaesthetists and midwives.

title: great attention and treatment
body: I was collected by ambulance from PAH Harlow on 17 Apr. and taken to Basildon for angioplasty, and returned the same day by same crew. From beginning to end I had the best attention possible, Ambulance Crew, Reception and treatment all first class.  all displayed care, comfort and reassurance in a professional but friendly manner. I cannot express my gratitude enough.

readBy.name: Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Great Practice and Staff
body: Having visited the pharmacist for my other half I was told to contact our doctor asap as he only has 1 Kidney and it was thought he had an infection. Within 5 minutes of calling the surgery I received a call back and within 30 minutes I was able to collect the prescription. We were nervous about changing doctors, however it was for the best.

title: Exceptional service from GP, dispensary and…
body: Recently I have developed acute sciatica which needed urgent medication. My GP promptly issued the required medication, the dispensary dispensed the medication almost immediately and telephoned my husband to advise it was ready to collect. Given the current situation and the pressure on GP surgeries especially the dispensary, I cannot speak highly enough of the service I have received. Thanks to all.

title: Polite staff especially in these testing times
body: Seen promptly and very polite staff. Query dealt with efficiently. Very understanding and friendly in these difficult circumstances and times.

title: Horrible experience - badly organised hospital
body: The hospital is overall very badly organised. I received a call saying I needed to come for an appointment for a radiology - with the person on the phone not being able to tell me if it is for an x-ray or ultrasound nor for which part of the body. I go to radiology for the said appointment and I am told, that since I am pregnant, I need to go to women's health. I go to women's health and they say they have no appointment for me and ask me to go back to radiology. I have spent then 40min walking around the hospital between the green zone and yellow zone without being able to talk to someone who can tell me what this appointment is about. I arrive back at radiology and push them to confirm if I have an appointment or if the call I had received was a joke. Finally, I am able to speak to someone who confirm it is for an ultrasound and finds which room I need to go to...but turns out they wanted me to have a kidney ultrasound...which I already had in the past. Complete waste of time. I spent over 1h walking around the hospital trying to figure out what this appointment was for. It's really unnecessary to call patients and play with them like ping pong during a pandemic! This is not the first time I suffer from this hospital badly organisation, I have had a couple of appointments at women's health moved, without being told which as a result meant I missed some appointments. They really need to put a better organisation system in place.

author: FEB20
title: Great birth experience and care
body:
I gave birth to my second baby by elective section at the RAH Paisley in February.  
My antenatal care at the Mid-Argyll Maternity Unit was fantastic from start to finish. My assigned midwife Karen was amazing with her professional and personal care. Karen was great at reassuring me and keeping my anxiety at bay with relaxation sessions during my antenatal visits which were a huge benefit to me. I was delighted when Karen made it possible to be with us at my section for support. The theatre team were brilliant, very friend, calm and accommodating towards us. It was a really special experience having my midwife who cared for me throughout my pregnancy at the birth. Karen went above and beyond with her support and care and we were very grateful.  
Thank you to the maternity team at the RAH for their great care and to Karen and her team at the Mid- Argyll a special thank you. I was sad to say goodbye at the end of my postnatal visits.

author: talonjj87
title: Alcohol
body:
Brilliant.  
Very helpful with regular contact and advice from both counsellors and nurses

author: chachaqr36
title: I love all the staff
body: I love all the staff and I really mean that, now they are being taken away, I like everything you do. You are great people and I couldn't wish for any better. I would choose to have you all visit me again. I feel you are like friends to me.

author: Post
title: Calm, organised and upbeat.
body:
My GP recently referred me to the MAU at RAH. I cannot praise the staff highly enough. Everyone was professional and kind and I felt I was in really safe hands.  
Considering the current pressure, on all staff in the NHS, the unit was calm and organised and the atmosphere was upbeat. Thank you team MAU, you are a credit to NHS GG&C.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: greenqq35
title: Pleased and happy
body:
- Making me meals & Drinks  
- Very pleased & happy with the IRIS team involvement  
- The IRIS team made me smile and laugh at times  
- Nobody better has looked after me.

author: fi scotland
title: Thank you is not enough
body:
Great care from dedicated caring wonderful staff ward 8 at Wishaw general.  
My dad was admitted very unwell and was confirmed Covid positive. The staff were wonderful about keeping us informed and never complained when we called to check how he was doing. They helped him with the mobile phone so he could call us and also arranged a time for a zoom call so dad could see his new great grand daughter.  
They took such great care of him that he is now back home and at 83 years of age this was nothing short of a miracle.  
Thank you.
